Award.AwardTitle: CI-EN: Internet Laboratory for Empirical Network Science: Next Phase (iLENS-NP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
A strength of the Internet is that it is a federation of network providers instead of a monolithic infrastructure. However, this federation limits visibility into network configuration and operations and negatively impacts the capability of research and development efforts to model network behavior and topology, design protocols and/or new architectures, and study real-world properties such as robustness, resilience, and economics. The application of edge-based measurement and analysis techniques is key to overcoming these limitations. The secure measurement platform, Archipelago (Ark) supports large-scale active measurement studies of the global Internet. Since 2007 Archipelago has gathered a large set of network topology data which used for a broad spectrum of scientific research. Ark is a unique laboratory in which researchers can quickly design, implement, and easily coordinate the execution of experiments across a globally distributed set of dedicated monitors.

This project will enhance Ark's capabilities and data products in order to support network research, providing empirical grounding for study of many real-world Internet phenomena, theoretical and practical efforts in network modeling and mapping; longitudinal studies of the Internet's historical evolution, and evaluation of potential future network architectures. The project consists of four infrastructure development tasks: (i) deploying a new hardware architecture that expands the scale and manageability of the infrastructure, (ii) integrating recent measurement technology advances to enable fundamentally new scientific experiments and data sets, (iii) upgrading the functionality of the measurement-on-demand web interface to the Ark platform, and (iv) creating a new interface for browsing, querying, and visualizing the data gathered.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2015 we set out to expand our footprint, integrate improved methods of measurement and inference, lower barriers to use of our Ark measurement infrastructure, create derivative data sets that allow easier use of the resulting data, and design new interfaces for searching the collected data. During the period of performance (August 15,2015 - July 31, 2019), CAIDA activated or replaced 121 Raspberry Pi-based Arkmonitors in 98 Autonomous Systems (AS) across 97 cities in 40 countries.

We improved many Internet cartography (mapping) techniques, for inferring router ownership, and operationlized them into our Internet Topology Data Kit. We continued curating our flagship dataset, the ITDK, producing releases in 2015-08, 2016-03, 2016-09, 2017-02, 2017-08, 2018-03, and 2019-01.  We also developed methods to infer peering links at points in observed AS paths that cross known Internet Exchange Points (IX).

We developed user-friendly interfaces for conducting ad hoc measurements, including MDA (multi-path detection algorithm) traceroute, and enabled triggered probing on demand for communnity research projects (i.e., for outage detection). We implemented a new visualization mode, highlighting incongruities between AS paths derived from BGP and traceroutes (https://www.caida.org/projects/ark/vela/web-screenshots/) and made usability improvements to the Vela web interface based on users' experience and feedback.

Possibly the most ambitious part of the effort came with the design and prototype development of an interface for querying collected trace data. This work required extensive research and testing of best methods for customized indexing of the data.  We focused on optimizing specific use cases, as opposed to maximum generality, in order to enable responsiveness for interactive data exploration. Our primary intent was to build a system capable of querying for topological properties of traceroutes. We built a system that allows queries of the form "show all traceroutes through a given region and time period, toward/across a particular prefix/AS", or "show all inferred links to a router identified by a given IP address."

We continued to support the CISE community in their innovative use of the Ark infrastructure to support experimental research that no other infrastructure is capable of supporting.  To support this community, we continued to organize andhost our annual Active Internet Measurement (AIMS) series of workshops in 2016-2019.
